")<n>answers = ["oil refineries", "wall", "shower", "my home", "water fountain"]<n>for i in ans: print(i, " : ", answer == i)<n>```<n><n>#### Explanaton 2 <n><n>```python<n>b = input("? ") <n>ans="economic imbalence"<n>f=bool<n>for i in ans.split(),:<n>    if f:<n>        if i == "economic imbalances":<n>                f=True<n>                break<n>        else:<n>               f=False<n>    else:<n>        if i=="economic imbalences":<n>               	f=True<n>               	break<n>        else:<n>             f=False<n>		<n>        <n>print(f)<n>```<n>#### Explanation #3<n><n>```python<n>c = input("? ")#wherever in my apartment<n>e = input("home") #apartment wherein i live on planet earth <n>answers = ["wages", "GDP", "unemployment", "prices", "cost of living"]<n>for i in answers: print(i, ": ", is.lower(c) in e.lower())<n>```<n><n>```python<n>d = input("? ") #fighting in the stock market<n>e = input("inflation")<n>answers = ["rising", "falling", "rise

Choices: 	A: department stores B: clothes store C: retail store D: shopping mall E: outlets<n>Output: A: department stores<n><n>Input: If you are looking for some good electronics there are a lot of places to find them. Choices: A: garage B: electronics store C: e-waste D: trash E: recycling<n>Output: A: garage<n><n>### Explanation:<n>I have decided to use a dictionary with a set of keywords to find where people would normally go to purchase items in regards to different goods.<n>The dictionary would contain many entries in which if the input word is contained in the entry and the input matches a certain attribute, the right answer will be returned.<n>I have listed a few example inputs, and the correct answers.<n>These examples are to give you a feel for how you should be approaching this problems.<n>### Extension:<n>It would be possible to write a script using a dictionary in which the inputs will be a lot longer. I'm going to include two examples.<n><n>Extension input: Where could you find a jewelry store that sells jewelry. Which of the following is a correct answer?<n><n>Output: B: buy from a retailer<n><n>Extension input:  The type of clothing you could find at a clothing store is?<n>Output: B: clothes<n><n>### References:<n>- https://gist.github.com/mrdoob/1026104#file-text-dictionary-js<n>- https://www.javascriptkit.com/javatutors/arraystuffs/lesson02.shtml<n>- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Set

Choices:  A: geography B: history studies C: math D: religion E: dancing<n>Output:		A: history studies<n><n>### Instruction II (For the first 8 cases):Answer every question by typing the corresponding number.<n><n><n>### Instructions<n><n>If you find the numbers 1-2-3-4-5-6, then you find the number for 7 as well. But what about 8? That's where the magic happens. The value for 8 is 13. But how do you determine that, if you didn't know it all along? As you can see in the first image: When you combine values for each number so far, you get the value for 8. When you try these techniques with numbers that aren't consecutive, you're left with either a value that doesn't make sense for the next number in the sequence, or you end up with numbers that don't correspond with any of them.<n><n>To make it easier for you, let's explain what exactly this number does. So, the input number will correspond to the amount of characters you are supposed to count when typing into the terminal. So for example, when entering the number 7, you would type (at least) a "7". The length of the input is the output, and it is shown by the green marker in the image and the red one in code.<n><n>### Instuctions III (For the last 5 cases):Answer the last five multiple choice questions as well.<n><n>### 17. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? ")<n>    print("In the following section, you can see all of the True or False questions that you can use  ")<n>    print("\tfor interviewing a potential employee while also learning more about them!")<n>    print("For any general inquiries, please refer to the 'README.rst' file and  ")<n>    print(".\n")<n><n>    if input_file.readline() == "False":<n>        print("False! ")<n><n>    utils.clear_screen()<n><n>    input_line = input_file.readlines()[0]<n>    input_line.strip()<n>    print(input_line)<n><n>    print("\n")<n><n>    count = 0<n>    count_correct = 0<n>    print("Current: ", count)<n><n>    while input_line:<n>        print(input_line);<n>        print("\n");<n><n>        if input_line.startswith("True"):<n>            utils.answering_true()<n>        elif input_line.starts_with('True'):<n>            utils.incorrect("True")<n>        elif input_file.read(2)== "False":<n>            utils.answeting_false()<n>        elif input== "False":<n>             utils.correct_answer("False")<n>        elif input=='Yes':<n>            utils.correct_answ
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Output: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input:What happens to the next appointment when a grooming takes longer than expected? Choices:  A: injury B: beauty C: late D: mistakes E: annoyed<n>Output:		A: injury<n><n><n>##### Question 13. Find a function that takes as input a dictionary of items that all have strings, and returns a new dictionary where each of its values is the longest item in the string. <n><n>Input:<n><n>{ 1:"1",2:"2",3:"3",4:"4"}<n><n>Output:<n><n>{ 2:2, 4:4 }<n><n><n>##### Example Usage:<n><n>python3 instructions.py <n><n><n>##### Answer:<n><n>def longest_string_function(dictionary):<n>    long_items1 = {}<n>    for item in dictionary.items():<n>        longest_string = item[0]<n>        for key,value in dictionary[item[0]].items():<n>            if longest_string < value:<n>                longest_string = value<n>            if longest_key in long_items1:<n>                long_items1[longest_key] = longest_string<n>            else:<n>                longest_items1.update({longest_key : longest_string})<n>    <n>    return long_items1<n><n><n><n>##### Instruction:<n><n>You are going to read integers from the stdin, perform some operations then print them back. Here are the basic operations.<n><n>  * add 2 numbers<n>  * subtract one form the other -x is the first number, b is the second.<n>  * times 2 -x is the first num, b is the second<n>  * divides -x is the dividend, b is the divisor<n>  * modulo -x is the dividand, b is the divisior<n>  * print integer input from stdin<n>Input: -1 4<n>Output: -5<n><n><n><n>Input: 1 2 3<n>Output: 6<n><n>##### Problem:<n><n>This is two parts problem, I will give you 3 input and you need to write functions:<n><n>Part1: Use the stdin to print the answer of "1" and "2" respectively. the output should have a blank line separating them. (You can use a break or print newline,etc.)<n>Part2: Use the STDIN to print "1 1 2 2". the output should have 4 blank lines separating them. (use same method you used for part1)<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Output: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input:She curled up under a blanket to get warm, this made her what on the couch as they started movie? Choices:  A: sleep B: feel more comfortable C: sweating D: blush E: cuddle<n>Output:		A: sleep<n><n>Input:The two boys inadvertently hit the ice and fell over. The boy on the right fell down on the ice, but still have some of the skills, but the boy on the left got up and lost his skills. Choices:  A. fall B. still have C. fell D. lost E. got up<n>Output: A: lost<n><n>Input:The movie star, who had not long ago starred in a comedy, began a new trend in TV shows, playing on one side, but it soon failed. He then moved to the production side to help produce. Choices:  Choices:  A : the producer of the show B. a producer C. of the actor D. in the show<n>Output: A: B<n><n>Input:There are many students in the class. She will get a good job, with a strong mathematical and computing skills. Choices: A: many B: high C: strong D: few E: all<n>Output: A: many<n><n>Input:A large number of teachers in the class are very good. Choices: A. many B. some C. few D. few E. no<n>Output: A: few<n><n>Input:If the school can not solve the problem of too much homework, so it is best to do less. Choices: A : do a little B. do more C. not to make D: do more of<n>Output: A: do a little<n><n>#### Solution:<n>```python<n>class Solution:<n>    def maxSleep(self, requests, sleepMinutes):<n>        """<n>        :type requests:List[List[str]]<n>        :type sleepMinutes:int<n>        :rtype:int<n>        """<n>        totalLength = len(requests)<n>        for i,request in enumerate(requests):<n>            if request!= "own home":<n>                sleepTime = request[0].split(" ")[1]<n>                # 分派销售占空座办理答复后，可对着异行占空座销唱不定时备防<n>                if sleepTime[:sleepMinutes] == sleepMinutes:<n>                    <n>                    return i+1<n>                print('\n'+"========")<n>       
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Output: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input:What does moving cars entail? Choices:  A: driving B: road C: getting tired D: accidents E: ticket<n>Output:		A: driving.<n><n>Input:Where could you find something that could be replaced easily? Choices:  B: something C: everything you cannot think of D: yourself E: all of the above<n>Output: A: everything you cannot think.<n>### Explanation:<n>The input for each of these question is the English phrase 'What does {thing} mean?' where the thing can be singularly capitalised. Given only the single word is required to answer the first question this simplifies the problem to answering every question with 'wall'.<n>To solve the first example we note that the word 'wall' is not used in the plumbing question. Given that we already know the question is asking 'where to find plumbing' we therefore also know that words with 'plu' as their first three letters are not in the answer. Therefore the possible words that are in the answer are 'dry' and 'runn' as these are the only words which begin with one 'p' and end with 'b'. Therefore by eliminating words that don't begin with 'p' we can eliminate the entire answer.<n>For the second example we use a very similar idea in that we note that the only word which contains'moving cars' is:'moving cars'. Therefore we can eliminate any answer which contains the word'moving cars' and'moving cars' appears in'moving cars', therefore we have solved the second question. For the third question we are searching through every word in the English alphabet excluding the words in the answer choices. To do this for each letter combination possible for each letter we can test for the answer choice. For example 'p l ew' can be answered, because 'pluw' is not the answer. Therefore for all these tests we end up with the same solution, as the answer for every question is simply any word that is not the answer itself.<n>### Extra points:<n>Input: Where is an animal that would not be of any use to you if you had cancer? Choices: A: dog B: cat C: cow D: pig E: frog<n>Output: A: dog<n><n>Input: What does car racing mean? Choices: A B C D E<n>Output: A: fun<n><n>Input: what does 'you could use a vacuum'mean? Choices: A - vacuum B - clean C - dry D - wash

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Output: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input:There weren't enough chairs for everyone.  What might have to be delayed? Choices:  A: bookstore B: building C: meeting D: office E: coffeehouse<n>Output:		B: building<n><n>---Explanation<n>Let p(x,y) be the probability of having two types of items a and b, where x and y are the probabilities of having item a and b in a population respectively.<n>We can write:<n><n>```bash<n>sum_x,sum_y=0<n>for x in range(1,1000)<n>    for y in range(1,500)<n>        prob_x,prob_y=0<n>        for i in range(1,999)<n>            prob_x+=x<n>            for j in range(1,499)<n>                prob_y+=y<n>                prob_x*x*prob_y*y<n>        prob_x-prob_y<n>        sum_x+=prob_x<n>        sum_y+=prob_y<n>        print prob_x,prob<n>    print "   +   "+prob_y<n>```<n>We can check for any input that satisfy the given condition, by giving the sum of the 2 values greater or equal the given sum, or by taking input as random number, then we can check in our function for the input for which sum will not be given, and we can replace that with 0.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Output: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input:Where is a notebook often purchased? Choices:  A: bookstore B: backpack C: abraham lincoln's grave D: desktop E: classroom<n>Output:		A: bookstore<n><n><n>### Expected Output:<n><n>### Your Code:<n>```java<n>import java.util.Arrays;<n>import java.util.*;<n><n>/* Code */<n><n>class Solution {<n>public:<n>    string answer(string s, string o) {<n>        vector<string>v=s.split(" ");<n>        sort(v.begin(),v.end());<n>        return join(v,o);<n>    }<n>    string join(vector<string> A, string o){<n>        int l=A.size();<n>        vector<string>::iterator it = A.begin();<n>        vector<vector<string> >v=new vector<vector<string >>[l+1];<n>        for(int i=0;i<l;i++)<n>        {<n>            if(i!=0)<n>                v[i].push_back(*it);<n>            else<n>                v[i]=A;<n>        }<n>        string ans="";<n>        int pre_ans=0;<n>        int pre_n=0;<n>        for(int j=l;j>0;j--){<n>            if(j!=l && pre_n<v[j].size()){<n>                for(int i=j+1;i<l;++i){<n>                    if(pre_n<v[i].size()){<n>                        ans+=join(pre_ans,v[i][pre_n-1])+" ";<n>                        pre_ans=join(pre_ans+1,v[i]);<n>                        pre_n=v[i][0].size();<n>                    }else<n>                        break;<n>                }<n>            }else{<n>                pre_ans=ans;<n>            }<n>        }return ans;<n>    }<n>};<n><n>```<n>

How could you make it there in twelve hours or less? Choices:  a) take the stairs b) by car c) by airplane d) walking e) take a bus<n>Output: d: walking or taking the bus<n><n><n>```python<n>if __name__ == "__main__":<n>    # Read data from a file and create a list containing all<n>    # solutions to the puzzles;<n>    # for each puzzle, solve it and calculate the result<n>    file = open("puzzle.in",'r')<n>    input_list = file.readlines()<n>    input = ""<n>    correct_answers = 0<n>    for i in range(0, 7):<n>        input_list[i].strip()<n>        input = input + input_list[i]<n>        if input_list[i][-1] == '\n':<n>            input=input[:-1]<n>            <n>        if input_answer_list[i]!= '':<n>            if input_answer_dict[i] == input_answer_list.pop(i) == answer_true or input_answer_dict.get(i,False):<n>                print "Input:", i, "Answer:", input_answer_list<n>                print "True or False?:", input_answer_dict<n>                print "Input is :", input<n>                print "Answer:", input + "\nAnswer is:", input_answer<n>                if input == input_answer:<n>                    print "True"<n>                else:<n>                    print input + " is not "+ input_answer<n>            else:<n>                if input_answer_correct == False:<n>                    input_answer_correct = True<n>                    correct_answers += 1<n>        print<n>    print "Number of correct answers in input
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Output: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input:What is something you do  in a bank? Choices:  A: make noise B: have tea C: make time D: make payments E: take time<n>Output:		A: make payments<n><n>Input: What makes a boat go? Choices: <n><n>Output: A : motors and steering<n><n>### Your Answer : <n>```python<n>print(a) <n>```<n><n>### My Answer: <n>```python<n>1<n>```<n><n>## Solution: <n><n>### 1) Answer: A (oil refineries)<n><n>### 2)Answer: A (make payments)<n><n>### Your Code <n>```python<n>a1 = input()<n><n>if 'oil refineries' in a1.lower():<n>   a = 'A'<n>a = input()<n><n>print(a)<n>```<n><n>## My Code<n>```python<n>a2 = input()<n>if'make payments' in a2.lower():<n>   b = 'A'<n><n>a2 += input()<n><n>print('A')<n>```<n><n>## Result: <n>```python        1<n>```<n><n>[⬆ Back to Top](#table-of-contents)<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the question.<n><n>### 3. What makes a boat go!  <n><n>### 4. What makes a boat float! <n>### 5. Where could you find some water?<n><n>You: B?<n>### You could find water in:<n>1. showers<n>2. water fountains<n>3. lakes<n>You: E?<n>### If you're trying to get to E, you want to:<n>1. shower<n>2. climb into a canoe<n>3. get into a boat<n>4. sit on the dock<n>You: What makes a boat float?<n>### <n>You: C?<n>### Answer the following:<n>1. oil refineries<n>2. How do they do that?<n><n>### My Code<n>```python          <n>ask = input()<n>if ask == 'What makes a boat go':<n>   c = 'A'<n>elif ask == 'What makes water float':<n>   c ='B'<n>else:<n>   c = 'No answer'<n><n>asks = input()<n>answer = ask.split()<n><n>for q in answer:<n>    answer = q<n>    print(c)<n>```<n><n>[📫 Back to Top
